comments:
Starting from versoion 3.2 Eclipse IDE sporadically hangs in different places.
Processor usage goes 100% and program does not respond to attempts to kill it for several minutes (regardless is it done by Alt-F4 on its window or from TaskManager Applications tab). If kill javaw.exe process from TaskManager processes tab Eclipse dies momentanly, but it take a while to reach that tab due to processor usage. This is why this bug is higher then normal priority.

There is impression that bug is associated with network operations as it mostly occurs when some network resource is unreachable (some examples - hangs in update manager, hangs on XML validation, hangs on data platform operations, e.g. testing connections). But some cases seems to be not network-dependent, e.g. on invoking of pop-up menus in Project Explorer and Java Editor.

This behavior exhibits itself at least on 3 different computers with different hardware and slightly different Eclipse configuration (e.g. different plugin sets). None of them had such issues with Eclipse 3.1 (in all cases Eclipse 3.2 was installed in separate folder in strict accordance with installation recommendations).

JDK version Sun JDK 1.5 (1.5_06 and 1.5_08).

Regards,

Oleksandr Alesinskyy

Oleksandr, what exactly do you have installed?  There seems to be many factors here working together, some of which (e.g. xml validation) are not coming from the Eclipse SDK proper.

Does the problem occur when you only have the Eclipse SDK installed?

Hello,

as I have written problem occurs on 3 different computers with different plugins installed. As far as I can see additional plugins they have in common are DTP and WTP only. First time Eclipse 3.2 has hanged right out the box, before any additional plugin has been installed.

To the moment it has hanged in 2 additional points - on code completion in Java editor (Ctrl-S?ace) and on Quick Hierarchy  (Ctrl-T). In both cases functionality is available after restart.

It seems that there are several components affected here, including non-SDK ones.

I suggest restricting this bug report to the JDT-related troubles only (e.g. ctrl+T etc)

I will move the bug to the JDT/UI inbox to follow up on these claims.

Oleksandr, if you can isolate wtp and dtp related bugs, you should open a bug against those components.

Yes, it is clear that it is exceptionally hard to solve bug that can not be reasonably isolated and, even worse, is intermittent. 

The problem is that bug manifests itself in many different places. Definitely, it is possible that there are many bugs with identical symptoms, but, from my point of view, it is much more likely that bug is caused by some core component that is used by all components affected by bug. This is why I have reported it here.

As I have mentioned 3.1 version with the same set  of plugins (sure, different version numbers) has not exhibited such bhavior.

Please attach dumps when eclipse hangs next time, see
http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/How_to_report_a_deadlock#Getting_a_stack_trace_on_Windows

>There is impression that bug is associated with network operations as it mostly
>occurs when some network resource is unreachable
Did eventually something change in your network or firewall (assuming you do not run 3.1 and 3.2 in parallel and hence it's not sure whether 3.1 still "works").

Do you eventually use a different VM with 3.2?

No, seems to be unlikely, for following reasons -
1. Hangs occur both in office and at home, it is very unlikely that network/firewall settings has changed there simultaneously.

2. First hang has occured in few minutes after installation (so, I would say in half an hour or less after I ceased to work with 3.1). No known to me network/firewall changes during this interval.

3. JVM is the same (1.5_08).
Ok, so it really looks like something introduced in 3.2.1. Please create attach  stack traces whenever you experience the problem. This will help us hunt it down.

Sorry, first of all problem has appeared in 3.2, not in 3.2.1. I had a great hope that 3.2.1 would solve it, but my hope failed.

Secondly, I'm unable to attach stack traces - as there is no exception. Just in some moment Eclipse completely hangs (100% processor usage in javaw.exe) and the whole system becomes unresponsive - it takes several minutes to bring up task manager.

>Secondly, I'm unable to attach stack traces
See my previous link whic explains how to do the stack dumps.

(In reply to comment #8)
Then please try to set the priority of the java.exe to BelowNormal after launching Eclipse (or Low, if it's still not enough). This should help preventing the application from absorbing all processor power.
Don't apply comment 10 when providing stack trace.

Sorry, I have overlloked the link in your previous comment. Will do traces on next hang.

Concerning priority - this I have tried before, it really helps to cope with system on hang, the only problem here is that I from time to time forgot it.

BTW, it would be nice if eclipse.exe will have command-line switch to start javaw with lower priority then eclipse.exe.

> BTW, it would be nice if eclipse.exe will have command-line switch to start
> javaw with lower priority then eclipse.exe.

Process priorities are system-dependent, so I doubt there will be an Eclipse command line switch. On WinXP, this should do the job:

    start /BELOWNORMAL eclipse.exe -consolelog
Eclipse.EXE is system-dependent anyway.

now Eclipse has hanged next time (was started eclipse -consolelog).
I have tried Ctrl-Break, no reaction in 3 minute, no stack traces.
Then I just killed java.exe.

> I have tried Ctrl-Break, no reaction in 3 minute, no stack traces.
> Then I just killed java.exe.

And the console window had focus when you pressed Ctrl+Break?
I guess you need to give it more than 3 minutes. Without a stacktrace, there's really no way we can help you.

Console window definitely has had focus. Next time I would let it think it out overnight :) Really, 3 minutes should be enough. 

There is other possibility - I can not rule out that I just pressed wrong key combination - it was on notebook with German keyboard, so this assumption is not really so stupid, as it looks on first glance.

Anyway, would try it once more on next hang.
Just try to press Ctrl+Break in the Console without being in a livelock to see whether you need to press a Fn key or something on your notebook.

Thank you.

This I have done _before_ I have tried do it for Eclipse, but I still have a vague feeling that I have pressed another key while Eclipse hangs (I was quite frustrated, as it hangs at very unappropriate moment).

Sorry for troubling.
As Markus said, simply try it out now and you will get a stack dump.

When Eclipse does not hang I can obtain stack dump (as I have mentioned I have tried it before hang). During the hang I was unable to obtain it - why other matter, probably it was my stupidity, probably it just won't generate. 

Now I have wait till next hang.

No more hangs for 4 days, but now, as I run Eclipse with java.exe and lower priiority it started to die from "Out of Memory" (sometimes regular memory, and sometimes PermGen). I have increased both values substantially, but for no use.

-vmargs -XX:MaxPermSize=160m
-Xms40m
-Xmx512m

Before reportin Out of memory processor goes to 100% for ~1min, and then message comes.

>Before reportin Out of memory processor goes to 100% for ~1min, and then
>message comes.
And why didn't you do the stack dump and attach it here?
I was not sure that it is the same error, but if you like, would do it next time. BTW, I forgot to mention that sometimes even "Out of memory" messoge does not come and Eclipse dies silently.

BTW, here is one of stack dumps

Created an attachment (id=53360)
Stack trace

I have started Eclipse with the following configuration (eclipse.ini)
-vmargs 
-XX:MaxPermSize=512m
-Xms40m
-Xmx1024m

It still runs out of memory PermGen space after some hours. I'm pretty sure that there is memory leak and, in some cases, out of space condition causes infinite(?) loop in error handler (as in previously attached file).

To which component leak shall be attributed I'm not sure (while last time I have done nothing else as editing Java code and looking into XML file), but loop in error handler is definitely in the remit of core components.

Regards,

Oleksandr

Regarding the exception from comment 25 and comment 27, please file a separate
bug for the providers of the org.eclipse.xsd plug-in (I think this is unrelated
to the OutOfMemory problems).

Moving to Platform/Runtime for the PermGen problem. I think this is the same as
bug 153485 or bug 92250.

Oleksandr, running with a 1.6 VM might give you a stacktrace for the OOME, see
http://bugs.sun.com/bugdatabase/view_bug.do?bug_id=4753347 .

Concerning bug from comments 25 and 27  - it is filed, bug 162775,
(https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=163775).

Concerning bug 92250 - yes, it seems to be (almost) a duplicate of it.
The only difference, that sometimes Eclipse crashes and sometimes hangs. So, it seems to be a bug in the error handler that _sometimes_ manifest itself on top of PermGen space bug. I'm as well almost sure, that I have seen a couple of times hangs on top on "normal" (i.e. not PermGen OOME). Will post stack dump as soon as it occurs once more (they are much more rare as PermGen OOME).
Concerning JDK 1.6 - will try.

Thank you and best regards,

Oleksandr

I might have the exact same problem, and it occurs in 3.2 and all higher versions upto and including 3.3m5eh. For me the bug usually occurs when I do something like:
- Open a .jsp (causing the WTP JSP structured editor to load initially)
- Open an .xml (causing the WTP XML se to load initially)
- open a context menu in the project explorer.
I always have at least WTP and Subversive installed. It feels like the hang often occurs when opening something for the 1st time but I am not sure.

I did a few dumps while the thingy is looping and will add them as an attachment to this bug. The log also contains a jmap -heap and jmap -histo dump.
